>>15071660

Israel and Stewart. They are two authors that came up with a reasonable seeming approach to relativistic hydrodynamics in the 70s (60s?)

QFT that is weakly out of equilibrium is just hydrodynamics. The QFT just tells you about the microscopics of the fluid but at large scales all that matters are things like transport coefficients and the equation of state.

Einstein's equations in asymptotically AdS space have been shown to be dual to the relativistic version of the Navier-Stoke's equation. It's just a valid classical to classical duality called the fluid-gravity correspondence and you don't need to believe in string theory to use it.

These technologies are on the way to becoming protected and strictly legislated utilities - even when the service is provided by private companies. Ah, no no no, you misunderstand Anon. I'm not suggesting actually transmitting the actual feeling itself, or even more dystopic; imposing it on another human. Though, that would certainly be an incredible accomplishment from scientific perspective I strongly believe that the only truly unassailable and inviolable freedom that all humans possess is the freedom of thought. Putting it the way you do is to me an even more demented version of teaching a child love and physical intimacy by savagely molesting and abusing it.

What I'm talking about, purely conveying information is no more invasive or mind altering than reading a poem or touching sandpaper. The challenge is actually -defining- the language of this method of communication.
It's a circular problem in nature. You need to have a way to convey some kind of information in order to convey a shared language in the first place.
Which is why thoughts and emotions have been out of the scope so far. Conveying the meanings of a verbal language is aided by gestures and examples. Say sound ->point to green object ->repeat sound ->point towards a second object that only share the characteristics of being green.

As you mention early versions of a chip like this would be limited to very basic electric signalling No. What the starting point would be is analogues to something like Euclid's elements. We need a baseline. Our point in space and definition of a line. Like Euclid's work it'll probably only be a simplified definition but it'll work for now.
I think the emotions that are best suited as our reference points are the most ingrained primal ones we have. Stuff that has been an integral part of our biology since the first nerve cell existed. Hunger? Pain? Aversion? Pleasure? A sleeping state and a wakeful state? I'm not sure. Opposite ends of the spectrum would be best of course.

>>15068587
>Beyond Elon hate, which seems awfully popular around here, how exactly is this a bad thing?

I see where Elon is going with this, and where he's going isn't "help disabled people". That's the short term goal, yes, not the long term one. If they can get this standard/easy/safe via the disabled, they can use it on the mainstream.

The first dimension is brain/machine interface for a normal healthy person, and that's where some of the hate comes from via an ethical concern. Is it secure? What happens if someone hacks it? The fear is mind control. Lots of sci-fi on this topic. The potential upside is enormous of course.

Second dimension is clinical immortality, the timeless rich person fantasy. If I have an 80's car (human body metaphor), something will always break - transmission, battery, tire.. there's no "magic part" that makes it run forever, anything can and will break with time. The same logic means there's no magic medicine for human immortality. But I want to immortalize the brain of the car, the computer, I can put it in another car (brain transplant), remove it and wire it up to a support system (analogous to soviet dog head experiments), or copy the data and run on an emulator (neuralink). All the rich people go after life extension, but realistically this is the only way we'd have a meaningful way to do it in our lifetimes if ever. This modality is what will drive the customer base - given the choice between scary brain hacking and death, many will choose the former.

>>15072278
Yes, with the caveat that we define "the universe" as "everything that is visible with our telescopes." The total number of atoms in the universe is estimated at 10^82. That's a very large number, but also significantly smaller than the total number of possible 4chan posts. This doesn't maintain under cosmic inflation, a popular cosmological theory, because then there would be an infinite amount of space and matter.

We have 26 letters we can use, in upper or lower case. You can also write in Russian, Hebrew, Arabic, etc., but we can ignore that. With 52 letters from both cases and say 38 more characters from numbers and punctuation marks, we get 90 possible characters.

We also get 2000 characters to a post.

So, there would be 90 possie posts with 1 character. 90^2 for two characters, all possible combinations, 8,100 possibilities, 729,000 for three, 65+ million for four, and very quickly you can see how this gets to be a very big number.

There are 90^2000 possible 4chan messages, which absolutely dwarfs the number of atoms.

>what happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object?

>It is a common thought experiment to consider what would happen if an unstoppable force were to meet an immovable object. However, this scenario is purely theoretical and cannot occur in reality.

>In classical mechanics, it is impossible for an object to be completely immovable, as there is always some resistance or friction that will cause the object to move to some extent when a force is applied to it. Similarly, it is impossible for a force to be completely unstoppable, as there will always be some limit to the amount of force that can be applied.

>Therefore, in the real world, it is not possible for an unstoppable force to meet an immovable object. Any force that is applied to an object will be met with some level of resistance, and the object will either move or remain at rest depending on the relative strengths of the force and the resistance.

>Are these ultra massive BHs the product of galactic mergers alone or is there some other mechanism?
The reigning theory is that in the early universe you had black hole stars that aren't possible under the current conditions. Normally, when a star is formed it ejects the matter around it as it fuses or novas, but back when the universe was much hotter and denser, there was no where for that extra matter to go, so the star would simply feed back on itself, forming a star some billion times larger than the largest star today with a black hole being force fed at its core, constantly in a state of nova. Eventually things spread out and cooled down enough to leave those gigantic cores behind, which form the largest of the supermassive black holes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It is not possible to change the color of a person's eyes naturally after they have developed. The color of a person's eyes is determined by the amount and type of pigments in the front part of the iris, as well as the scattering of light by the tissue in the iris. These factors are determined by genetics and cannot be changed.

There are some medical procedures that can alter the appearance of the iris, such as iris implants or iris pigmentation, but these are not natural processes and carry risks and potential complications. It is important to understand the potential risks and benefits of any medical procedure before considering it.

It is possible for a person's eye color to appear to change over time due to a variety of factors, such as the amount of melanin in the iris, the aging of the iris, and the presence of certain medications or diseases. However, these changes are usually subtle and do not result in a significant change in eye color.

>>15072354
>Are you just inventing shit to argue against? I never said anything about a cyclical model.
>My point is nature found a way to stop the runaway greenhouse before.
>If I had to guess what stopped it, it could be numerous things: more cloud cover from more evaporation, increased co2 uptake rate by plants at higher ppm, volcanic activity, etc.
The actual answer is that a "runaway greenhouse" is literally not possible with an atmospheric volume like the kind we have. CO2 has a very well-known falloff where it takes increasingly higher volumes to get any appreciable change in energy retention, and we're already pretty close to where that is. Doubling the amount in the atmosphere would barely increase the amount of IR energy intercepted, in or out.

This entire silliness involving runaway greenhouse effects is based on cursory observations of Venus, whose climatic history is essentially unknown to modern science. But even on a simple review of the data you can see that their atmosphere is 93 bar (substantially denser) and 96.5% CO2. It's a far cry from the measly 400 ppm on Earth, some 0.04%.

No it is true. Speed and gravity alter the rate at which we travel through time. Speed and gravitational pull both slow down time. So one can "travel into the future" by going into space and traveling very fast, or by hanging out by something that has lots of gravity.

Satellites in orbit around the earth experience a slightly different rate of time. This is important to know for engineers who need to synchronize clocks between computers on the Earth and computers on satellites. I am a programmer and I knew someone who wrote code for satellites that had to take that into account.

>>15071168
Your bullet point summary of relativity is really wrong. It is funny that you think relativity pioneered the idea of mirrors.

One detail you got really wrong, is the idea that relativity permits traveling back in time. It doesn't. Time gets slower as you approach the speed of light, and it is not possible to exceed the speed of light. So in order to go back in time, you would have to go faster than the speed of light, which is impossible.

I don't know all the details about relativity, but I do know that a big milestone in proving relativity to be true was proving that light bends around objects with lots of gravity. When Einstein developed relativity, the theory predicted that light coming from the planet Mercury that has to pass right over the surface of the sun would not travel in a straight line, but rather it would bend around the surface of the sun under the sun's immense gravity. That was a novel hypothesis that could have easily falsified relativity, but to everyone's surprise light did in fact behave that way when they checked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yes, that's actually a common symptom of adhd

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's normal to feel more motivated to do tasks that you find enjoyable or meaningful, and to feel less motivated to do tasks that are tedious or mundane. This is true for everyone, not just people with ADHD.

It's also normal to feel more motivated to do tasks when you have a clear sense of purpose or when you feel a sense of accomplishment after completing them. On the other hand, tasks that feel pointless or lack purpose can be demotivating.

For people with ADHD, it can be especially challenging to maintain motivation for tasks that are routine or require sustained attention. This may be due to the way that ADHD affects the brain's ability to regulate attention, emotion, and behavior.

If you find that your lack of motivation is interfering with your ability to complete important tasks, it may be helpful to work with a mental health professional to identify strategies that can help you stay motivated and manage your ADHD symptoms. Some strategies that may be helpful include setting clear goals, breaking tasks down into smaller steps, using rewards or incentives to motivate yourself, and finding ways to make the task more enjoyable or meaningful. It may also be helpful to work with a therapist or coach to develop coping skills for managing the challenges of ADHD and to learn how to better regulate your emotions and behaviors.

>>15070952
It's understandable that you would feel frustrated if you struggle to maintain motivation for tasks that you don't feel like doing. However, it's important to recognize that it's normal for people to have ups and downs in their motivation and that everyone has to do things that they don't feel like doing at times.

While medication may be helpful for some people with ADHD in managing their symptoms and improving their ability to focus and concentrate, it's important to recognize that medication is just one aspect of treatment and may not be the sole solution for all challenges related to ADHD.

It may be helpful to work with a mental health professional to identify other strategies that may be helpful in managing your lack of motivation and in improving your ability to complete tasks that you don't necessarily enjoy. Some strategies that may be helpful include setting clear goals and breaking tasks down into smaller, more manageable steps, finding ways to make the task more enjoyable or meaningful, and using rewards or incentives to motivate yourself. It may also be helpful to work on developing coping skills for managing your emotions and behaviors, and to learn how to better regulate your attention and focus.

Chemistry but I've heard the same from engineers and other scientists. We have a group of high schoolers coming through the labs for a tour in a month and the teams have been brainstorming ways to discourage them from our fields (managers don't know this).
I'm biased because I live in Australia where there's few opportunities so the job market here sucks and pays poorly for a lot of work.
I did an accelerated undergrad so my first year was compressed into ~6 months and I did an advanced degree so my last year was research based. No masters required to go into a PhD if you already have a research degree/experience here.
In general science and engineering jobs here suck. And I mean "even with dual incomes a bank will never give enough to get a mortgage within a 1 hour commute of anywhere with jobs no matter how many degrees you have" kind of suck. There's some exceptions if you don't mind doing FIFO or transferring into non-science/engineering roles but then I don't really count those roles as being based on your degree since you could get there with less time and money wasted.

Honestly I'm just salty because work has been extra shit recently and I look at my friends/family who never even graduated but self-taught programming who now make more than my boss' boss and think I should have stuck to keeping science as a hobby and done something else to earn money.

>>15055284
>I would like to do research later.
>Is it just because its hard to get a job / to get a position or is the work bad?
not him but I also did chemistry and now work in research in industry. It's doable but you should be aware that it's certainly not the easiest path towards earning a comfortable living, assuming that's what you care about the most. I consider myself lucky that I managed to get a research position straight after a masters. I earn a decent enough salary for my age and where I live (although that's UK so most wages are shit), but nothing exceptional. I could have earned more doing some generic shit like engineering, comp sci, finance or whatever, with a less competitive job market and less occupational hazards to boot - although the latter is part of the fun if you ask me.
The work is enjoyable but this depends a lot on where you work and how much you enjoy your field of study. As for difficulty getting a job, I'd say you need to be top 25% of your cohort grade-wise, and make a real effort to get some form of internship before you graduate for there to be any sort of guarantee.

It's like the saying, you are the sum of the fife people closest to you. Same goes for the information you get. What is your input? What do you read, what do you watch?
If you're into maths or physics and have never read the words of the great mathematicians and physicists, then that's the mistake. And I don't talk about secondary and tertiary literature, I mean their original works. Have you read Euclid, have you read Euler, have you read Poincaré?
Same goes for every other field. Go to the source and get the knowledge without a filter. Try to cut out mediocre authors, just consume the brightest of old days and of today. They will inevitably influence you; even if you never get on their level, but even if you reach 5% of them you're already miles ahead of everyone else that learns from average people.

In whatever field you are, try to get the whole picture. You have to develop intuition for it, so that even if you see something new you already know the answer or at least know what you have to do. You have to gain complete mastery in a field, that will probably take you 10 years.

And then study another field as a hobby. But do it with the intention to gain deep understanding and recognize patterns. Maybe you will see connections between those fields, maybe you can create something completely new by connecting those fields.
For example, if you are a chemist and study computer science as a hobby, you could develop a software for chemist that could become the industry standard, because it's so much better than the alternatives. But there are so many ways to combine different fields. Don't give up, I believe in you.

>>15070745
I can't think of any countable distribution which doesn't make sense except for maybe the Poisson which comes from the limit of Binomial, and in general, the Le Cam's theorem.

For uncountable distributions, they actually do come from pretty much nowhere. Someone will find a function somewhere whose integral over [math] \mathbb R[/math] converges, then a statistician will normalise it, and find out how it coincidentally explains a lot of data; or they will play around with an existing distribution and perhaps generalise it. A lot of the popular ones though do have mathematical explanations but they require some [math] heavy [/math] math such as measure theory, which is why their proofs are often left out even in very mathematical statistics book like Casella & Berger.

But it's really all about Law of Large Numbers. The Gaussian distribution comes from Law of Large Numbers, the Strong variant of which you will not find proved in any undergraduate statistics book. Then Xi squared comes from t-tests. Cauchy distribution, comes from playing around with Normal. Uniform is self-explanatory. Exponential comes from the exponential decay of half-life of atoms, and can be understood very clearly from it relationship with the Poission distribution. The rest: Beta, Gamma, etc., are just generalisations of previous distributions. I feel Blitzstein does a good job of providing intuition for all the distributions, but the math in it is extremely sloppy. I don't know enough measure theory to recommend any books on that.

>>15070175
Sure, so first you need to know a little about elliptic curve: you can think of an elliptic curve [math]E[/math] defined over [math]\mathbb{Q}[/math] (we're working over [math]\mathbb{Q}[/math] to keep it simple) as the zero locus of a polynomial of the form [math]y^2-x^3+ax+b[/math], with [math]a,b[/math] rationals (I know it sounds a bit too specific when you hear it the first time, but there are good reasons why such curves are interesting). Now a bit of a caveat, to make things run more smoothly we need to "complete" this curve by adding a point at infinity, that we call O. Again, there are very good reasons for this
Of course, you can try to find a zero [math]P=(x,y)[/math] with rational coefficients, and we call [math]E( \mathbb{Q})[/math] the set of all such points. This set is actually an abelian group, its addition is cute from a geometric standpoint but ugly from an algebraic standpoint. You can find the details on wikipedia or anywhere really. We call [math]E( \mathbb{Q})[/math] the Mordell-Weil group.
An important result about this group is the Mordell-Weil theorem saying that it is finitely generated.

Now, onto families of varieties: what does wikipedia mean by "elliptic surface [math]E \to S[/math]"? It means that [math]S[/math] is the projective line [math]\mathbb{P}^1[/math], it's a line with an added point at infinity; and basically, for each [math]s \in S[/math], you can take the fiber [math]E_s[/math] (think the set-theoretic inverse image of [math]s[/math]), and we require that this fiber be an elliptic curve, for each [math]s[/math].
In laymen's terms, we are provided with a family of elliptic curves [math]\{ E_s \}[/math] indexed by [math]s \in \mathbb{P}^1[/math].

Now as we know, for [math]s[/math] fixed we have [math]E_s(\mathbb{Q})[/math] finitely generated, so we may find what wikipedia calls a basis up to torsion, say [math]P_1(s),\dots , P_r(s)[/math]. Now the real challenge lies in "patching" these choices of point together

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15071819
By which I mean: when we let [math]s[/math] vary, will my point [math]P_1(s)\in E[/math] vary "nicely" (think continuously)? When this happens we say that [math]P_1(s)[/math] is a section of [math]E\to S[/math].
Of course we may ask the same of [math]P_2,\dots, P_r[/math].
If we manage to choose a basis up to torsion [math]P_i(s)[/math] for each [math]s[/math] in such a way as to make each [math]P_i(s)[/math] a section, then we call these [math]P_1(s),\dots, P_r(s)[/math] a basis up to torsion of my elliptic surface.

Now this turns out to be a very difficult question to answer (we actually don't even know how to find explicit [math]P_1,\dots, P_r[/math] for fixed [math]s[/math]!), but the Cox-Zucker machine does something more humble: if we feed some sections [math]P_1(s),\dots,P_r(s)[/math] into it, it will tell us whether they actually get the job done, i.e. it checks whether they actually are a basis up to torsion, and algorithmically at that

>>15070524
Off the mark Anon. The game never ceased. It simple shifted. When the environment change and survival depends on securing the basics; Food, safety, shelter - the dealer runs a positive-sum game. Social beings, humans included, generally achieve better hunt and survival chances as individuals when acting in concerted action. The thing is however, scurrying and scrambling to escape predators or find food and stay dry stopped being a problem round abouts 60-40k years ago when we decided towns and tribes of more than 30-150 smelly relatives were a good idea. Fast forward a bit and the positive-sum game is history, so what's the problem? Well, the game doesn't end untill the last complex organic molecule in the world toss a pair of snake eyes, it's just that the rules periodically change while the game is session. The players are never told when this happen, they usually discover the rules the hard way when it cost them their seat at the table. A few short millenia ago the rules changed and the game changed from blackjack to poker. Now they're not competing against the dealer, they're competing against their former partners. The positive-sum game turned into a zero-sum game.
From a proliferating construct's perspective the absence of growth constraints means it's limited solely by the proliferation of the competitors who occupy the same space. That's why we got so smart. That's why we have this grotesquely overdeveloped lump of gray goo in our skulls consuming an absurd share of our energy. The only cases runaway overadaptation occurs in nature is when a selection criteria is both unceasingly applied and the pressure grow at a rate that matches the organism's iterative and constantly improving adaptations over generations - like when the selection criteria is both a survival dependency and a mirror image of yourself - your fellow man and the society you both depend on to thrive.
You're not overshooting shit, you're just off-target.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It absolutely does have volume. Take any immersion of the Klein bottle into R^3, then do a partition of unity thingy, 1 = sum_i lambda_i(x).
Each patch is diffeomorphic to a region in R^2, and as such it has volume. I.e. if the region is parametrized as t_i(x,y) i=1,2,3, then the volume is
[math]\int_{R \subset \mathbb{R}^2} \lambda_i(x,y) ||\frac{dt}{dx} \times \frac{dt}{dy}|| dxdy[/math]

Some concerns to be addressed
>The lack of bibliography
These papers have been translated from my mother tongue into english. All bibliography is was kept and will be added in due time, my intent is to write 10 or so documents just like these. The choice of words for the reference section is to be taken as a joke, it will be discarded.
>The emphasis on contextualization
Occult philosophy is inherently axiomatic, yet all traditions differ in their interpretation. I think it is important to look at the history of the subject and familiarize the reader with the material before going deep into abstraction. I cite authors and name their works when imperative.
>The choice of formalism used
Even though magic itself is axiomatic, we must keep in mind two very important things. That these axioms can be expressed in all manner of different formalisms and that this is an elusively empirical science.
The ideas discussed in these documents are expressed in the language of differential geometry and will be further developed in that of algebraic topology.
>The deterministic idealization
I hope that after reading the papers you will come to understand that the even the general notions of this matter are incompatible with non deterministic descriptions of what is or what it will be. >>15069936
In a sense magic is all about moving information to different places, allowing it to have material consequences. Practical magic can roughly be divided into two branches:
>Projective
Creates a well defined set of information and aims to distribute it to another subset of the space where thoughts reside
>Receptive
Aims to catch particular information by establishing a relationship between what they aim to look for and the set that embodies it.

Practitioners of the first are what you may commonly think of as alchemists, ceremonial magicians, witches and the like. Those who study the second aspect are seers, readers and remote viewers.
If you read the papers you'll see that it is quite easy to prove someone is legitimate
>having two shamans perform a "spirit animal" operation and be the case that both coincide on the same animal for a sufficiently large number of people
>having a practitioner manifest something unlikely in a controlled environment, like a coin toss that lands on heads an arbitrarily large number of times in a row
The issue with this is that other people's perception and thoughts contribute to a manifestation, it is not a closed system. This means that experiments should either be done by an honest team of believers in the occult or that these are to be concerning things that are known only to a small number of people prior to peer review.

The current state of magic is unregulated and in the future we should expect to hand out licenses that validate a "magician" and their credibility. There is an association which already does these things for shamans, employing the methods I mentioned earlier:
https://www.shamanism.org/

There are several magical orders which also deem members to be initiated once they can reproduce consistent results by unequivocally occult means but I cannot vouch for their standards being better than those of the Michael Harner Foundation.

Paul Dirac
>I tried to appreciate it, but I did not get very much success in trying to appreciate philosophy. I feel that philosophy will never lead to important discoveries. It’s just a way of talking about discoveries which have already been made.

Richard Feynman:
>I rapidly learned that philosophy, as far as I was concerned, the philosophers who were respected were really quite poor and rather stupid people — at least, from the modern point of view. It seems to me that there were trivial errors in logic which were obvious. Very poor, it seemed to me.

Steven Weinberg: http://joelvelasco.net/teaching/167win10/Weinberg%20against%20philosophy.pdf
>The value today of philosophy to physics seems to me to be something like the value of early nation-states to their peoples. It is only a small exaggeration to say that, until the introduction of the post office, the chief service of nation-states was to protect their peoples from other nation-states. The insights of philosophers have occasionally benefited physicists, but generally in a negative fashion—by protecting them from the preconceptions of other philosophers.

Stephen Hawking:
>Traditionally these are questions for philosophy, but philosophy is dead. Philosophy has not kept up with modern developments in science, particularly physics. Scientists have become the bearers of the torch of discovery in our quest for knowledge.

>>15055344
>What can be done about science not being perceived as glamorous?
Promote the achievements and successes of scientists: Highlighting the contributions that scientists have made to society can help to make science more glamorous and show the important role that it plays in our lives.

Make science more accessible: Many people may feel intimidated by science and feel like it is not for them. Making science more accessible and approachable, through activities like science festivals and demonstrations, can help to make it more appealing to a wider audience.

Encourage media coverage of science: Science-related news and events can often be overlooked in favor of more sensational headlines. Encouraging media outlets to cover science stories can help to make it more visible and appealing to a wider audience.

Support science education: Providing students with access to high-quality science education can help to spark their interest in the subject and encourage them to pursue careers in science.

Show the diversity of science: Science is not just for a select few, and showcasing the diversity of people who work in the field, including people of different genders, races, and backgrounds, can help to make it more attractive and inclusive.

>>15070085
[math]\mathbf{Theorem.}[/math] There are infinitely many primes.
[math]\mathbf{Proof.}[/math]
Base case: There are infinitely many primes greater than n.
Induction step: There are therefore infintely many primes greater than n-1.

And so on, until you reach n=0. But 0 is not a prime, contradiction. Therefore there are infinitely many primes. [math]\qed[/math]

posts.com:
The natural numbers are countable.
Every infinite subset of a countable set is countable.
The prime numbers are a infinite subset of the natural numbers.
Therefore, the prime numbers are countable.
Since both the natural numbers and the prime numbers are countable, they possess the same cardinality.
Q. E. D.
